```{r}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(scales)
library(readr)
```
```{r}
# ============================================================
# Load dataset
# ============================================================
df <- read_csv("youtube_shorts_tiktok_trends_2025_labeled.csv")

# ============================================================
# Friday-only scatter + loess trend line
# Title Length vs. Average Watch Time
# Custom JS-style contrasting colors and clean minimal theme
# ============================================================
g_plot_out <- ggplot(friday_df, aes(
  x = title_length, 
  y = avg_watch_time_sec, 
  color = viral
)) +
  
  # Scatter points (light with transparency)
  geom_point(aes(color = viral), alpha = 0.35, size = 1.7) +
  
  # Smooth trend line (LOESS captures nonlinear shape)
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, size = 1.2) +
  
  # Custom contrasting palette (JS-style dark + vibrant blue)
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "Non-viral" = "#0096C7",   # bright blue
    "Viral"     = "#0A2A43"    # deep navy
  )) +
  
  # Axis + legend labels
  labs(
    x = "Title Length",
    y = "Average Watch Time (Friday)",
    color = "Viral Status"
  ) +
  
  # Base minimal theme for clean look
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  
  # Fine-tune theme: remove grid, add axis lines, adjust text
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),                       # remove background grid
    axis.line  = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = 0.6),
    axis.ticks = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = 0.6),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 20),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "#4F4F4F"),
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )
```

```{r}
ggsave(
  filename = "friday_title_length_watchtime_600dpi.png",
  plot = g_plot_out,
  width = 10,        # inches
  height = 6,        # inches
  dpi = 600
)
```
